items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: ‘Mexsicko City’ Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
items.abstract: Even amid other environmental gains, it is the improvement in air quality that has most burnished the city’s green credentials.

items.title: Engineers Bring Processes of Nature to Design
items.abstract: Morphogenesis, from the Greek words morphê, for shape and genesis, for creation, refers to imitating evolution in developing designs.

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: Michigan’s Failure to Protect Flint
items.abstract: The state, which had played down findings of high levels of lead in the city’s water, must step in to find solutions.

items.title: Anger and Scrutiny Grow Over Poisoned Water in Michigan City
items.abstract: The state’s investigation into lead contamination of Flint’s drinking water follows the governor’s request that President Obama declare the problem a federal emergency.

items.title: Rural Oregon’s Lost Prosperity Gives Standoff a Distressed Backdrop
items.abstract: Areas that were once economically important languish as jobs are clustered in urban centers, creating a feeling of powerlessness as their populations grow older, poorer and less educated.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: Some Workers Need Jobs as Much as Builders Need Workers. Cities Connect Them.
items.abstract: In tight labor markets, developers and local leaders are using major projects to provide residents with careers in construction.

items.title: A Beloved Provence-Based Wicker Workshop Comes to Paris
items.abstract: This week, Atelier Vime unveils its new showroom and a collaboration with the American artist Wayne Pate.

items.title: To Save East River Park, the City Intends to Bury It
items.abstract: A plan to protect the Lower East Side from flooding was just rejected by the city, replaced with a drastic revision that costs twice as much but does not disrupt traffic.

items.title: New York City Food Carts Get Their First Report Cards
items.abstract: On Friday, the health department began issuing letter grades (most of them As) to street vendors. Reactions ranged from enthusiasm to shrugs.

items.title: The L Train Smells Bad. No, Really, It Smells Very, Very Bad.
items.abstract: For a third day, subway riders are reporting a strong odor of gas at stations in Brooklyn. Riders and M.T.A. workers have said it is making them sick.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
items.abstract: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.
keywords: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

items.title: A Mayor and the Challenge of Making the City Safer
items.abstract: Eric Adams made public safety a campaign issue. Now, as mayor, he will be held accountable.

items.title: Mayor Adams Promotes ‘Radically Practical’ Agenda in Washington
items.abstract: Eric Adams spoke at a national gathering of mayors and focused on the importance of cities demonstrating that government can work.

items.title: Review: At City Ballet, Giving Voice to the Body, With Sneakers
items.abstract: Justin Peck’s “Partita,” set to Caroline Shaw’s Pulitzer-Prize winning composition, opened New York City Ballet’s winter season at Lincoln Center.
